paragraphs.text:
%md
# About This Lab
**Objective:** Explore data using Pair RDDs. Explore the web server log files,
and the user account data, using key-value pair RDDs.
**File locations:** 
    Exercise directory: /home/training/training_materials/devsh/exercises/pair-rdds
    Data (HDFS): /warehouse/tablespace/external/hive/devsh.db/accounts
                 /devsh_loudacre/weblogs
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Aggregating Data with Pair RDDs

---

msg.data:
About This Lab

Objective: Explore data using Pair RDDs. Explore the web server log files,
and the user account data, using key-value pair RDDs.
File locations:

Exercise directory: /home/training/training_materials/devsh/exercises/pair-rdds
Data (HDFS): /warehouse/tablespace/external/hive/devsh.db/accounts
             /devsh_loudacre/weblogs

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons: Aggregating Data with Pair RDDs

# Setup
---

The following cells ensure that this notebook can run from top to bottom without errors any number of times.

msg.data:
Setup

The following cells ensure that this notebook can run from top to bottom without errors any number of times.

paragraphs.title: Load data in HDFS if it does not exist

hdfs dfs -ls /devsh_loudacre/weblogs

msg.data: <font color="red">Previous livy session is expired, new livy session is created. Paragraphs that depend on this paragraph need to be re-executed!</font>

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab
---

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore Web Log Files

In this section, you will create a pair RDD based on data in the weblogs data files, and use that RDD to explore the data.

**Tip:** In this exercise, you will be reducing and joining large datasets, which can take a lot of time and may result in memory errors resulting from the limited resources available in the course exercise environment.
To avoid this problem, perform these exercises with a subset of the web log files by using a wildcard: textFile("/ devsh_loudacre/weblogs/*2.log") includes only filenames ending with 2.log.

Using map-reduce logic, count the number of requests from each user.
a. Use map to create a pair RDD with the user ID as the key and the integer 1 as the value. (The user ID is the third field in each line.) 
Your data will look something like this:

```pyspark
(userid,1)
(userid,1)
(userid,1)
...
```

b. Use reduceByKey to sum the values for each user ID.
Your RDD data will be similar to this:
```pyspark
(userid,5)
(userid,7)
(userid,2)
...
```

To avoid this problem, perform these exercises with a subset of the web log files by using a wildcard: textFile(“/ devsh_loudacre/weblogs/*2.log”) includes only filenames ending with 2.log.

Using map-reduce logic, count the number of requests from each user.
a. Use map to create a pair RDD with the user ID as the key and the integer 1 as the value. (The user ID is the third field in each line.)
Your data will look something like this:

(userid,1)
(userid,1)

...

b. Use reduceByKey to sum the values for each user ID.
Your RDD data will be similar to this:

(userid,7)
(userid,2)
...

paragraphs.title: 1 - Count the number of requests from each user
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
Use countByKey to determine how many users visited the site for each frequency.
That is, how many users visited once, twice, three times, and so on.
a. Use map to reverse the key and value, like this:

```pyspark
(5,userid)
(7,userid)
(2,userid)
...
```

b. Use the countByKey action to return a map of frequency: user-count pairs.

paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
Create an RDD where the user ID is the key, and the value is the list of all the IP addresses that user has connected from. (IP address is the first field in each request line.)
**Hint:** Map to (userid,ipaddress) and then use groupByKey.
```pyspark
(userid,20.1.34.55)
(userid,245.33.1.1)
(userid,65.50.196.141)
...
```
```pyspark
(userid,[20.1.34.55, 74.125.239.98])
(userid,[75.175.32.10, 245.33.1.1, 66.79.233.99])
(userid,[65.50.196.141])
...
```

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create an RDD where the user ID is the key, and the value is the list of all the IP addresses that user has connected from
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
### Join Web Log Data with Account Data
Review the accounts data located in /user/hive/warehouse/devsh.db/ accounts, which contains the data in the Hive devsh.accounts table.
The first field in each line is the user ID, which corresponds to the user ID in the web server logs.
The other fields include account details such as creation date, first and last name, and so on.

Join the accounts data with the weblog data to produce a dataset keyed by user ID which contains the user account information and the number of website hits for that user.

a. Create an RDD, based on the accounts data, consisting of key/value-array pairs: (userid,[values...])
```pyspark
(9012,[9012,2008-11-24 10:04:08,\N,Cheryl,West, 4905 Olive Street,...])
(2312,[2312,2008-11-23 14:05:07,\N,Elizabeth,Kerns, 4703 Eva Pearl Street,Richmond,CA,...])
(1195,[1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...])
...
```
b. Join the pair RDD with the set of user-id/hit-count pairs calculated in the first step.
```pyspark
(9012,([9012,2008-11-24 10:04:08,\N,Cheryl,West, 4905 Olive Street,San Francisco,CA,...],4))
(2312,([2312,2008-11-23 14:05:07,\N,Elizabeth,Kerns, 4703 Eva Pearl Street,Richmond,CA,...],8))
(1195,([1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...],2))
```
Display the user ID, hit count, and first name (4th value) and last name (5th value) for the first five elements. 
The output should look similar to this (but your example data may be different):
```pyspark
9012 4 Cheryl West
1123 8 Elizabeth Kerns
1093 2 Melissa Roman
...
```

(1195,([1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...],2))

Display the user ID, hit count, and first name (4th value) and last name (5th value) for the first five elements.
The output should look similar to this (but your example data may be different):

paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
# Result
**You have now:** explored the Loudacre web server log files, as well as the Loudacre user account data, using key-value pair RDDs.

---

msg.data:
Result

You have now: explored the Loudacre web server log files, as well as the Loudacre user account data, using key-value pair RDDs.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Solution
---

msg.data: Solution

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Spark Pair RDD
In Spark a key-value pair (KCP) are called a paired RDD. There are a number of pair RDD transformations. These
include `groupbyKey`, `reduceByKey`, and `join`. There are also pair RDD actions, such as `countByKey`.

msg.data:
Spark Pair RDD

In Spark a key-value pair (KCP) are called a paired RDD. There are a number of pair RDD transformations. These
include groupbyKey, reduceByKey, and join. There are also pair RDD actions, such as countByKey.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore Web Log Files

In this section, you will create a pair RDD based on data in the weblogs data files, and use that RDD to explore the data.

**Tip:** In this exercise, you will be reducing and joining large datasets, which can take a lot of time and may result in memory errors resulting from the limited resources available in the course exercise environment.
To avoid this problem, perform these exercises with a subset of the web log files by using a wildcard: `textFile("/ devsh_loudacre/weblogs/*2.log")` includes only filenames ending with 2.log.

Using map-reduce logic, count the number of requests from each user.
a. Use map to create a pair RDD with the user ID as the key and the integer 1 as the value. (The user ID is the third field in each line.) 
Your data will look something like this:

```pyspark
(userid,1)
(userid,1)
(userid,1)
...
```

b. Use reduceByKey to sum the values for each user ID.
Your RDD data will be similar to this:
```pyspark
(userid,5)
(userid,7)
(userid,2)
...
```

msg.data:
Explore Web Log Files

In this section, you will create a pair RDD based on data in the weblogs data files, and use that RDD to explore the data.

Tip: In this exercise, you will be reducing and joining large datasets, which can take a lot of time and may result in memory errors resulting from the limited resources available in the course exercise environment.
To avoid this problem, perform these exercises with a subset of the web log files by using a wildcard: textFile("/ devsh_loudacre/weblogs/*2.log") includes only filenames ending with 2.log.

Using map-reduce logic, count the number of requests from each user.
a. Use map to create a pair RDD with the user ID as the key and the integer 1 as the value. (The user ID is the third field in each line.)
Your data will look something like this:

(userid,1)
(userid,1)
(userid,1)
...

b. Use reduceByKey to sum the values for each user ID.
Your RDD data will be similar to this:

(userid,5)
(userid,7)
(userid,2)
...

paragraphs.title: 1 - Count the number of requests from each user
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Create an RDD based on a subset of weblogs (those ending in digit 2)
logsRDD = sc.textFile("/devsh_loudacre/weblogs/*2.log")

# map each request (line) to a pair (userid, 1), then sum the values
userReqsRDD = logsRDD.map(lambda line: line.split(' ')).map(lambda words: (words[2],1)).reduceByKey(lambda count1,count2: count1 + count2)

%sh
hdfs dfs -head /devsh_loudacre/weblogs/2013-09-22.log

paragraphs.title: 2 - Determine how many users visited the site for each frequency
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("JoiningDataUsingPairRDDs", "Show the count frequencies")
freqCountMap = userReqsRDD.map(lambda pair: (pair[1],pair[0])).countByKey()
print(freqCountMap)

%md
Use `countByKey` to determine how many users visited the site for each frequency. That is, how many users visited 
once, twice, three times, and so on.

a. Use map to reverse the key and value, like this:

```pyspark
(5,userid)
(7,userid)
(2,userid)
...
```

b. Use the `countByKey` action to return a map of frequency: user-count pairs.

Syntax
`freqCountMap = userReqsRDD.map(lambda (userid,freq): (freq,userid)).countByKey()`

once, twice, three times, and so on.

a. Use map to reverse the key and value, like this:

(5,userid)
(7,userid)
(2,userid)
...

b. Use the countByKey action to return a map of frequency: user-count pairs.

Syntax
freqCountMap = userReqsRDD.map(lambda (userid,freq): (freq,userid)).countByKey()

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create an RDD where the user ID is the key, and the value is the list of all the IP addresses that user has connected from
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Group IPs by user ID
sc.setJobGroup("JoiningDataUsingPairRDDs", "Create an RDD where the user ID is the key, and the value is the list of all the IP addresses that user has connected from")
userIPsRDD = logsRDD .map(lambda line: line.split(' ')).map(lambda words: (words[2],words[0])).groupByKey()

# print out the first 10 user ids, and their IP list
for (userid,ips) in userIPsRDD.take(10):
   print(userid, ":")
   for ip in ips: print("\t",ip)

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Join Web Log Data with Account Data
Review the accounts data located in `/user/hive/warehouse/devsh.db/` accounts, which contains the data in the Hive `devsh.accounts` table.
The first field in each line is the user ID, which corresponds to the user ID in the web server logs.
The other fields include account details such as creation date, first and last name, and so on.

Join the accounts data with the weblog data to produce a dataset keyed by user ID which contains the user account information and the number of website hits for that user.

a. Create an RDD, based on the accounts data, consisting of key/value-array pairs: (userid,[values...])
```pyspark
(9012,[9012,2008-11-24 10:04:08,\N,Cheryl,West, 4905 Olive Street,...])
(2312,[2312,2008-11-23 14:05:07,\N,Elizabeth,Kerns, 4703 Eva Pearl Street,Richmond,CA,...])
(1195,[1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...])
...
```
b. Join the pair RDD with the set of user-id/hit-count pairs calculated in the first step.
```pyspark
(9012,([9012,2008-11-24 10:04:08,\N,Cheryl,West, 4905 Olive Street,San Francisco,CA,...],4))
(2312,([2312,2008-11-23 14:05:07,\N,Elizabeth,Kerns, 4703 Eva Pearl Street,Richmond,CA,...],8))
(1195,([1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...],2))
```
Display the user ID, hit count, and first name (4th value) and last name (5th value) for the first five elements. 
The output should look similar to this (but your example data may be different):
```pyspark
9012 4 Cheryl West
1123 8 Elizabeth Kerns
1093 2 Melissa Roman
...
```

msg.data:
Join Web Log Data with Account Data

Review the accounts data located in /user/hive/warehouse/devsh.db/ accounts, which contains the data in the Hive devsh.accounts table.
The first field in each line is the user ID, which corresponds to the user ID in the web server logs.
The other fields include account details such as creation date, first and last name, and so on.

Join the accounts data with the weblog data to produce a dataset keyed by user ID which contains the user account information and the number of website hits for that user.

a. Create an RDD, based on the accounts data, consisting of key/value-array pairs: (userid,[values…])

(9012,[9012,2008-11-24 10:04:08,\N,Cheryl,West, 4905 Olive Street,...])
(2312,[2312,2008-11-23 14:05:07,\N,Elizabeth,Kerns, 4703 Eva Pearl Street,Richmond,CA,...])
(1195,[1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...])
...

b. Join the pair RDD with the set of user-id/hit-count pairs calculated in the first step.

(9012,([9012,2008-11-24 10:04:08,\N,Cheryl,West, 4905 Olive Street,San Francisco,CA,...],4))
(2312,([2312,2008-11-23 14:05:07,\N,Elizabeth,Kerns, 4703 Eva Pearl Street,Richmond,CA,...],8))
(1195,([1195,2008-11-02 17:12:12,2013-07-18 16:42:36,Melissa, Roman,3539 James Martin Circle,Oakland,CA,...],2))

Display the user ID, hit count, and first name (4th value) and last name (5th value) for the first five elements.
The output should look similar to this (but your example data may be different):

9012 4 Cheryl West
1123 8 Elizabeth Kerns
1093 2 Melissa Roman
...

paragraphs.title: 4 - Join the accounts data with the weblog data to produce a dataset keyed by user ID
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# Map account data to (userid,[values....])
accountsData = "/warehouse/tablespace/external/hive/devsh.db/accounts"
accountsRDD = sc.textFile(accountsData).map(lambda s: s.split(',')).map(lambda account: (account[0],account))

# Join account data with userreqs then merge hit count into valuelist   
accountHitsRDD = accountsRDD.join(userReqsRDD)

# Display userid, hit count, first name, last name for the first 5 elements
sc.setJobGroup("JoiningDataUsingPairRDDs", "Join the accounts data with the weblog data to produce a dataset keyed by user ID")
for (userid,(values,count)) in accountHitsRDD.take(5) : 
    print(userid, count, values[3], values[4])

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a pair RDD with postal code as the key and a list of names (Last Name,First Name) in that postal code as the value
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

namesByPCode = accountsByPCode.mapValues(lambda account: account[4] + ',' + account[3]).groupByKey()

%md
Create a pair RDD with postal code as the key and a list of names (Last Name,First Name) in that postal code as the value.

* **Hint:** First name and last name are the 4th and 5th fields respectively.
* Optional: Try using the mapValues operation.

msg.data:
Create a pair RDD with postal code as the key and a list of names (Last Name,First Name) in that postal code as the value.

  • Hint: First name and last name are the 4th and 5th fields respectively.
  • Optional: Try using the mapValues operation.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Sort the data by postal code, then for the first five postal codes, display the code and list the names in that postal zone

paragraphs.text:
%md
Sort the data by postal code, then for the first five postal codes, display the code and list the names in that postal zone. 
For example:

```pyspark
--- 85003 
Jenkins,Thad 
Rick,Edward 
Lindsay,Ivy 
...
--- 85004 
Morris,Eric 
Reiser,Hazel 
Gregg,Alicia 
Preston,Elizabeth 
...
```

msg.data:
Sort the data by postal code, then for the first five postal codes, display the code and list the names in that postal zone.
For example:

--- 85003 
Jenkins,Thad 
Rick,Edward 
Lindsay,Ivy 
...
--- 85004 
Morris,Eric 
Reiser,Hazel 
Gregg,Alicia 
Preston,Elizabeth 
...

# Tear Down

msg.data: Tear Down

paragraphs.title: Delete the Livy session
paragraphs.text:
%sh

sessionId=$(curl -s localhost:8998/sessions | jq '.sessions[0].id')
curl -s localhost:8998/sessions/$sessionId -X DELETE

msg.data: {"msg":"deleted"}
